bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, August 29, 1942

div1.p: Kellogg discusses his new magazine, "Army Doctor," for which he hopes to hire Siler as an advisor. He visited the Keans and will send Hench photographs of the visit.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, August 29, 1942
div1.opener:
41 East 42nd St.
N. Y. C.
THE
Carlton
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Aug. 29, 42
Dear Phil,
div1.p:
Ive been in Washington
two days and have seen
General Hillman who was very
kind but said he couldn't do
anything for me. I was glad to
be able to tell him the story
of The Army Doctor, myself, however.
Then saw Gardner who was
no longer angry and yet
stuck to his guns on many
points. He would like to
have the magazine sort of
an inspirational Sunday
School book with emphasis
on the heroism of Army Doctors
and the “to ye who are about
to die” angle - which only a
sentimental middle aged gentlemen
not well acquainted with the flesh
and blood doctors who are
going into service, would suggest.
I asked him to recommend
four good retired M. C.
officers, one of whom might act as a
paid - (and well paid) advisor
to our editor. Low and behold the
one he recommended hiphest
was your friend Col. Siler. I have
an appointment with him at his
home tonight. Col. Siler is now
THE
Carlton
WASHINGTON, D. C.
President of the Gorgas Institute
so Im not so optimistic about
his accepting the job-- but I'll
try to get him as I believe
he'll help me moderate Gardner's
views. Of. course I don't want
a Whizz Bang - which is about
what the August issue was-
and I'm ashamed of it- But
how popular it was with the
medicos may be shown by
the fact that of 70,000
copies sent to civilian physicians for the first time, with reply cards
asking to be placed on the
permanent mailing list-- we
THE
Carlton
WASHINGTON, D. C.
have already received 14,500
replies and it will run to
20,000 in the next ten days.

Murphy, our new editor
was ill advised on the August
issue, by a Jewish (smart)
Major in the M. C. at Camp Dix
who has taken a great interest
in the magazine. He's a prominent
neuropsychiatrist - but you
know how they are, - I'm eager
to talk to Siler.

Robin is with me - and we
spent an hour with the Keanes
yesterday afternoon who asked
all about you. I'll send you some
pictures next week

I promised Gardner a
framed “Conquerors of Yellow Fever”
picture for his home which he
was anxious to get. He thinks
it one of the finest paintings
in the world - which helped me
a lot. For a man who professes
such impeceable delicacy in the
realms of sex etc - he is the
most profane individual I've
met in a long time. If Col.
Siler comes with us I'll get
him to ask Gardner for an
article. I'm still only an advertiser
in the magazine but as I control
all the advertising they have- I
control the book in the last
analysis. We've had 123 letters
from overseas to date. That shows
the book is reaching the M. C. in
THE
Carlton
WASHINGTON, D. C.
our foreign bases -- and
that the first class mail idea
which is absolutely original for
a magazine - is really working.
Of course it goes first class
(6¢) only to Physicians in the
Army and Navy.

I hope you reached
Colorado without punctures
and that you find the new
station a good one.

Gen'l Hillman sent his regards.
He thinks you're going to be
tops in the Army and I agree.
